canonical_explanation.text: Plants are classified into herbs, shrubs, and trees based on their size and stem type. Herbs are small plants with soft, green stems (e.g., mint, coriander, wheat). Shrubs are medium-sized plants with hard stems that branch near the base (e.g., rose, jasmine, tulsi). Trees are tall, large plants with a hard, thick main stem called trunk (e.g., mango, neem, peepal). Climbers have weak stems and climb on supports (e.g., money plant, grapevine), while creepers spread along the ground (e.g., pumpkin, watermelon). Plants have different parts: roots absorb water and minerals and anchor the plant; the stem transports water and nutrients; leaves make food through photosynthesis; and flowers help in reproduction. Roots can be tap roots (one main root with branches, e.g., carrot) or fibrous roots (many thin roots from the base, e.g., grass). Leaves show either reticulate venation (net-like veins, e.g., mango leaf) or parallel venation (veins running parallel, e.g., grass). A flower has sepals, petals, stamens (male part), and pistil (female part).
rules: Herbs are small plants with soft, green stems.
Shrubs are medium-sized plants with hard stems branching near the base.
Trees are tall plants with a hard, thick stem called trunk.
Climbers have weak stems and use support to climb upward.
Creepers have weak stems and spread along the ground.
Roots absorb water and minerals from the soil and anchor the plant.
Stem carries water and nutrients between roots and leaves.
Leaves make food for the plant through photosynthesis.
Tap root: one main root with side roots (in plants with reticulate venation).
Fibrous root: many thin roots from the stem base (in plants with parallel venation).
Reticulate venation: net-like pattern of veins in a leaf.
Parallel venation: veins run parallel to each other in a leaf.
A flower has sepals, petals, stamens (male), and pistil (female).

questions.question_text: Which type of plant has a soft, green stem?
questions.explanation_correct: Herbs are small plants that have soft, green stems. Examples include mint, coriander, wheat, and tomato plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Trees have thick, hard stems (trunks). Shrubs have hard stems that branch near the base. Climbers may have soft or hard stems but they climb on support. Herbs are specifically defined by their soft, green stems.

questions.question_text: A rose plant is an example of a:
questions.explanation_correct: A rose plant is a shrub because it is a medium-sized plant with a hard stem that branches near the base. Other examples of shrubs include jasmine and tulsi.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A rose plant is too large and has a hard stem, so it is not a herb. It is not tall enough with a single trunk to be a tree. It does not spread along the ground like a creeper. It is a shrub.

questions.question_text: The thick, hard stem of a tree is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: The thick, hard main stem of a tree is called a trunk. The trunk supports the branches and leaves of the tree. Examples of trees include mango, neem, and peepal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Branches grow from the trunk. Roots are below the ground. Vine refers to climbing plants. The main hard stem of a tree is specifically called a trunk.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a creeper?
questions.explanation_correct: Pumpkin is a creeper because it has a weak stem that spreads along the ground. Other examples of creepers include watermelon, strawberry, and sweet potato.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mango is a tree. Money plant is a climber (it climbs on supports). Rose is a shrub. Pumpkin is the creeper among these options as it spreads along the ground.

questions.question_text: Climbers and creepers both have weak stems that cannot stand upright on their own.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Both climbers and creepers have weak stems that cannot stand upright on their own. The difference is that climbers climb on supports (like walls or other plants), while creepers spread along the ground.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Both climbers and creepers have weak stems. Climbers use external support to climb, while creepers grow horizontally along the ground.

questions.question_text: A student observes a plant that is medium-sized, has a hard woody stem, and the stem branches out near the base. This plant is most likely a:
questions.explanation_correct: A medium-sized plant with a hard woody stem that branches near the base is a shrub. Shrubs are shorter than trees and have multiple stems branching from near the ground.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Herbs have soft stems. Trees are tall with a single main trunk. Climbers need support to grow upward. The described features — medium-sized, hard stem, branching near base — are characteristic of a shrub.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs is CORRECT?
questions.explanation_correct: Neem is indeed a tree (tall, with a single hard trunk), and grapevine is a climber (weak stem that climbs on support). This is the correctly matched pair.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mango is a tree (not herb), mint is a herb (not shrub). Rose is a shrub (not tree), peepal is a tree (not herb). Wheat is a herb (not shrub), tulsi is a shrub (not creeper). Only option B is correct.

questions.question_text: Which part of the plant absorbs water and minerals from the soil?
questions.explanation_correct: Roots absorb water and minerals from the soil. They also anchor the plant firmly in the ground. Root hairs on the roots increase the surface area for better absorption.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The stem transports water and nutrients. Leaves make food through photosynthesis. Flowers are for reproduction. Roots are specifically responsible for absorbing water and minerals from the soil.

questions.question_text: The main function of the stem in a plant is to:

options.text: Transport water and nutrients to different parts

questions.explanation_correct: The main function of the stem is to transport water and minerals from the roots to the leaves, and food from the leaves to other parts of the plant. It also provides support to the plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Absorbing water is the function of roots. Making food is the function of leaves (photosynthesis). Producing seeds is the function of flowers/fruits. The stem's main function is transport of water and nutrients.

questions.question_text: Which part of the plant is mainly responsible for making food?
questions.explanation_correct: Leaves are mainly responsible for making food for the plant through the process of photosynthesis. They use sunlight, carbon dioxide from air, and water to produce food (glucose).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Roots absorb water and minerals. Stems transport materials. Flowers help in reproduction. Leaves are the food factories of the plant, carrying out photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: Which part of the plant helps in reproduction?
questions.explanation_correct: Flowers are the reproductive parts of a plant. They contain stamens (male parts that produce pollen) and pistil (female part that contains ovules). After pollination and fertilisation, flowers develop into fruits with seeds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Roots absorb water and anchor the plant. Leaves make food. Stems transport water and nutrients. Flowers are the specific parts responsible for reproduction in flowering plants.

questions.question_text: If you place a plant stem in coloured water, after some time the leaves show colour. This experiment demonstrates that the stem:

options.text: Transports water from roots to leaves

questions.explanation_correct: When coloured water is absorbed through the stem, the colour appears in the leaves, proving that the stem transports water from the roots upward to the leaves and other parts of the plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This experiment does not show food making, water absorption from soil, or flower production. It specifically demonstrates the transport function of the stem — carrying water upward to the leaves.

questions.question_text: A plant is uprooted from the soil. It will most likely die because:

options.text: Its roots can no longer absorb water and minerals from the soil

questions.explanation_correct: When a plant is uprooted, its roots are removed from the soil and can no longer absorb water and minerals. Without water and minerals, the plant cannot survive and will die.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While leaves may eventually fall off and flowers may wilt, the primary reason for death is that the roots lose contact with soil and cannot absorb the water and minerals essential for the plant's survival.

questions.question_text: The colourful part of a flower that attracts insects is the:
questions.explanation_correct: Petals are the colourful parts of a flower that attract insects and other pollinators. The bright colours and sometimes fragrance of petals help attract pollinators for pollination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sepals are usually green and protect the flower bud. Stamens are the male reproductive parts. Pistil is the female reproductive part. Petals are the colourful parts that attract pollinators.

questions.question_text: The male part of a flower is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The stamen is the male reproductive part of a flower. It consists of the anther (which produces pollen grains) and the filament (which supports the anther).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pistil is the female part of the flower. Petals are the colourful parts. Sepals are the green leaf-like parts at the base. The stamen is the male part of the flower.

questions.question_text: The female part of a flower is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The pistil (also called carpel) is the female reproductive part of a flower. It consists of the stigma (top), style (middle), and ovary (base) which contains ovules.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Stamen is the male part. Petals are the colourful parts. Sepals are the green protective parts. The pistil is the female reproductive part of the flower.

questions.question_text: The small, green, leaf-like structures at the base of a flower that protect the bud are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Sepals are the small, green, leaf-like structures found at the base of a flower. They protect the flower when it is in the bud stage. Together, all the sepals form the calyx.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Petals are colourful and attract insects. Stamens are male reproductive parts. Pistils are female reproductive parts. Sepals are the green protective parts at the base of the flower.

questions.question_text: The transfer of pollen grains from the stamen to the pistil of a flower is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Pollination is the process of transfer of pollen grains from the anther (part of stamen) to the stigma (part of pistil) of a flower. It can occur through wind, water, insects, or birds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Germination is the sprouting of a seed. Transpiration is the loss of water from leaves. Photosynthesis is the making of food by leaves. Pollination is specifically the transfer of pollen to the pistil.

questions.question_text: A tap root system has:

options.text: Many thin roots growing from the base of the stem
One main root with smaller side roots growing from it
Roots that grow above the ground

questions.explanation_correct: A tap root system consists of one main root (tap root) that grows straight down, with smaller side roots (lateral roots) branching off from it. Examples include carrot, radish, and mango.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Many thin roots from the stem base describes a fibrous root system. All plants have roots. Roots that grow above ground are aerial roots. A tap root system has one main root with branches.

questions.question_text: Grass has a _______ root system.
questions.explanation_correct: Grass has a fibrous root system where many thin roots grow from the base of the stem. There is no single main root. Other plants with fibrous roots include wheat, rice, and maize.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tap root system has one main root (found in plants like carrot). Aerial roots grow above the ground. Parasitic roots absorb nutrients from a host plant. Grass has a fibrous root system.

questions.question_text: Reticulate venation is seen in the leaves of:
questions.explanation_correct: Mango leaves have reticulate venation, where veins form a net-like pattern on the leaf. Plants with reticulate venation usually have tap roots. Other examples include peepal and rose leaves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wheat, grass, and maize all have parallel venation (veins run parallel). Mango is the plant with reticulate (net-like) venation among these options.

questions.question_text: In parallel venation, the veins in a leaf:
questions.explanation_correct: In parallel venation, the veins run parallel to each other along the length of the leaf. This is seen in monocot plants like grass, wheat, rice, maize, and banana.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A net-like pattern of veins is reticulate venation. Veins are never random or absent in leaves. In parallel venation, veins run parallel to each other.

questions.question_text: A student found that a plant has parallel venation in its leaves. The root system of this plant is most likely:
questions.explanation_correct: Plants with parallel venation generally have fibrous root systems. This is a general rule: parallel venation goes with fibrous roots, and reticulate venation goes with tap roots.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tap root system is generally associated with reticulate venation. There is a correlation between leaf venation and root type: parallel venation = fibrous roots, reticulate venation = tap roots.

questions.question_text: Meena observed a plant in her garden that was very tall, had a single thick hard stem, and many branches high above the ground. This plant is a:
questions.explanation_correct: A very tall plant with a single thick hard stem (trunk) and branches high above the ground is a tree. Trees are the largest category of plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Herbs are small with soft stems. Shrubs are medium-sized with stems branching near the base. Creepers spread along the ground. The described plant — tall, single thick hard trunk, branches above — is a tree.

questions.question_text: The process by which leaves lose water through tiny pores is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Transpiration is the process by which plants lose water in the form of water vapour through tiny pores called stomata on the surface of leaves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Photosynthesis is the process of making food using sunlight. Respiration is the process of releasing energy from food. Pollination is the transfer of pollen. Transpiration is specifically the loss of water from leaves.

questions.question_text: If you remove all the stamens from a flower, the flower will NOT be able to:
questions.explanation_correct: Stamens are the male parts of the flower that produce pollen grains. If all stamens are removed, the flower cannot produce pollen and therefore cannot carry out pollination from its own flower.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Petals still attract insects even without stamens. Sepals still protect the flower. Water absorption is a root function. Removing stamens specifically prevents pollen production.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly pairs the leaf venation type with its root type?
questions.explanation_correct: Plants with reticulate venation (net-like veins) generally have a tap root system. For example, a mango tree has reticulate venation and a tap root.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reticulate venation goes with tap roots (not fibrous). Parallel venation goes with fibrous roots (not tap). Aerial roots are a special adaptation, not related to venation type. Option C correctly pairs reticulate venation with tap roots.

questions.question_text:
A student classified plants as follows:
(i) Neem — Tree
(ii) Coriander — Herb
(iii) Money plant — Shrub
(iv) Jasmine — Shrub
Which classification is INCORRECT?
questions.explanation_correct: Money plant is a climber, not a shrub. It has a weak stem that needs support to grow upward. It climbs on walls, poles, or other plants. The other classifications are correct.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neem is correctly classified as a tree. Coriander is correctly classified as a herb. Jasmine is correctly classified as a shrub. Money plant should be classified as a climber, not a shrub.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Roots are important for a plant's survival.
Reason: Roots absorb water and minerals and hold the plant firmly in the soil.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct, and reason explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are correct, but reason does not explain the assertion
Assertion is correct but reason is incorrect
Assertion is incorrect but reason is correct

questions.explanation_correct: The assertion is correct — roots are vital for plant survival. The reason is also correct and explains why — they absorb water and minerals (essential for life processes) and anchor the plant firmly in the soil.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both statements are correct. Roots are indeed important for survival, and the reason correctly explains why — absorption of water/minerals and anchoring are the two main functions that make roots essential.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct order of parts from the outermost to the innermost in a flower?
questions.explanation_correct: From outermost to innermost, the parts of a flower are: Sepals (outermost, green, protective) → Petals (colourful) → Stamens (male part) → Pistil (innermost, female part).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct arrangement from outside to inside is: sepals first (they form the outermost whorl), then petals, then stamens, and pistil at the center. Only option B shows this correct order.

questions.question_text:
A student examined two plants:
Plant A: Has reticulate venation and a single main root going deep into the soil.
Plant B: Has parallel venation and many thin roots from the stem base.
Which is the correct identification?

options.text: Plant A has fibrous roots, Plant B has tap roots
Plant A has tap roots, Plant B has fibrous roots

questions.explanation_correct: Plant A with reticulate venation and a single main root has a tap root system. Plant B with parallel venation and many thin roots from the stem base has a fibrous root system. This follows the general rule.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reticulate venation correlates with tap roots, and parallel venation correlates with fibrous roots. Plant A's description matches tap root, and Plant B's description matches fibrous root.

questions.question_text: Plants with weak stems that need support to climb upward are called _______.
questions.explanation_correct: Plants with weak stems that need support to climb upward are called climbers. Examples include money plant, grapevine, pea plant, and bean plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Herbs are small plants with soft stems that can stand on their own. Shrubs have hard stems. Trees have thick trunks. Climbers are specifically plants that use support to climb.

questions.question_text: A green pigment found in leaves that helps in photosynthesis is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Chlorophyll is the green pigment found in leaves that absorbs sunlight and helps in the process of photosynthesis. It gives leaves their green colour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Haemoglobin is the red pigment in blood. Melanin is the pigment in skin. Carotene gives orange-yellow colour. Chlorophyll is the green pigment in leaves essential for photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: Insects visit flowers mainly to collect nectar. In the process, they help the plant by:

options.text: Carrying pollen from one flower to another (pollination)

questions.explanation_correct: When insects visit flowers to collect nectar, pollen grains stick to their bodies. When they visit other flowers, these pollen grains get transferred, resulting in pollination. This helps the plant reproduce.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Insects do not make food for plants or provide water. While some insects may eat pests, the main service they provide to flowers is pollination — transferring pollen between flowers.

questions.question_text: Which of the following plants has a tap root system?
questions.explanation_correct: Carrot has a tap root system. The carrot we eat is actually the enlarged tap root of the carrot plant. Other plants with tap roots include radish, neem, and mango.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wheat, rice, and maize are all monocots with fibrous root systems and parallel venation. Carrot is a dicot with a tap root system and reticulate venation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about herbs, shrubs, and trees is CORRECT?

options.text: Herbs always grow taller than shrubs
Shrubs have a single main trunk like trees
Trees have the thickest and hardest stems among the three
All herbs live for many years like trees

questions.explanation_correct: Trees have the thickest and hardest stems (trunks) among herbs, shrubs, and trees. The trunk of a tree is thick, hard, and woody, providing the strong support needed for its great height.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Herbs are shorter than shrubs (option A is wrong). Shrubs have multiple stems from near the base, not a single trunk (option B is wrong). Many herbs are annual and live for only one season (option D is wrong).

questions.question_text:
Match the plant part with its primary function:
(i) Root — (P) Makes food
(ii) Stem — (Q) Reproduction
(iii) Leaf — (R) Absorbs water and minerals
(iv) Flower — (S) Transports water and nutrients
questions.explanation_correct: Root absorbs water and minerals (R), Stem transports water and nutrients (S), Leaf makes food through photosynthesis (P), and Flower helps in reproduction (Q).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct matching is: Root — absorbs water (R), Stem — transports (S), Leaf — makes food (P), Flower — reproduction (Q). Only option A has all four correct.

questions.question_text: A flower that has sepals, petals, stamens, and a pistil is called a complete flower. Which of these parts, if missing, would mean the flower CANNOT reproduce?
questions.explanation_correct: Stamens (male part) and pistil (female part) are the reproductive parts of the flower. If either is missing, the flower cannot complete the process of reproduction. Sepals and petals are accessory parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sepals protect the bud and petals attract pollinators — both are helpful but not essential for reproduction. The essential reproductive parts are stamens (produce pollen) and pistil (contains ovules). Without either, reproduction cannot occur.

questions.question_text:
A student collected leaves from four different plants. She noticed the following:
Leaf P: Net-like veins
Leaf Q: Veins running side by side
Leaf R: Net-like veins
Leaf S: Veins running side by side
Which pair of plants is most likely to have tap roots?
questions.explanation_correct: Leaves P and R have net-like veins (reticulate venation), which is associated with tap root systems. Leaves Q and S have parallel veins, associated with fibrous roots.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants with reticulate (net-like) venation have tap roots, while plants with parallel venation have fibrous roots. Leaves P and R have reticulate venation, so they are most likely to have tap roots.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the key difference between a climber and a creeper?

options.text: Climbers have hard stems while creepers have soft stems
Climbers grow upward using support while creepers spread along the ground
Climbers are small while creepers are large
Climbers bear flowers while creepers do not

questions.explanation_correct: The key difference is the direction of growth: climbers grow upward by using external support (walls, poles, other plants), while creepers spread horizontally along the ground. Both have weak stems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both climbers and creepers can have soft stems. Size is not the distinguishing factor. Both can bear flowers. The key difference is that climbers grow upward with support, while creepers spread along the ground.

questions.question_text: Tiny pores on the surface of leaves through which exchange of gases takes place are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Stomata are tiny pores (openings) present on the surface of leaves. They allow the exchange of gases (carbon dioxide in, oxygen out) and also allow water vapour to escape during transpiration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Veins are tubes that transport water and food in the leaf. Petals are parts of flowers. Root hairs are on roots for water absorption. Stomata are the tiny pores on leaves for gas exchange.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes the function of each plant part?

options.text: Root — makes food, Leaf — absorbs water
Stem — absorbs water, Root — transports food
Leaf — makes food, Root — absorbs water

questions.explanation_correct: Leaves make food through photosynthesis, and roots absorb water and minerals from the soil. This is the correct pairing of plant parts with their functions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Roots do not make food (they absorb water). Stems transport (they do not absorb). Flowers help in reproduction (not food making). Only option C correctly pairs: leaf makes food, root absorbs water.

questions.question_text: The part of the stamen that produces pollen grains is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The anther is the top part of the stamen that produces and contains pollen grains. The filament is the stalk that supports the anther.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Filament supports the anther but does not produce pollen. Stigma is the tip of the pistil (female part). Ovary is at the base of the pistil. The anther is the specific part that produces pollen grains.

questions.question_text: Plants with tap roots always have reticulate venation in their leaves.
questions.explanation_correct: This is generally true. Plants with tap root systems have leaves with reticulate (net-like) venation. Similarly, plants with fibrous root systems have leaves with parallel venation. This is a general rule in botany.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is generally correct. There is a strong correlation between root type and leaf venation: tap roots go with reticulate venation, and fibrous roots go with parallel venation.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following characteristics:
(1) Soft, green stem
(2) Generally short in height
(3) Lives for one or two seasons
These characteristics describe a:
questions.explanation_correct: All three characteristics — soft green stem, short height, and living for one or two seasons — describe herbs. Examples include wheat, paddy, mint, and coriander.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Trees are tall with hard trunks and live for many years. Shrubs have hard stems. Creepers spread along the ground and may have other characteristics. All three features together describe herbs.

questions.question_text: A potted plant was kept in a dark room for three days. After this, its leaves looked yellow and the plant appeared weak. This happened because:

options.text: The leaves could not make food without sunlight

questions.explanation_correct: Without sunlight, the leaves could not carry out photosynthesis (the process of making food). Without food production, the plant became weak and its leaves turned yellow due to the breakdown of chlorophyll.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The roots would still absorb water in the dark. The stem would continue to transport. Flower wilting would not cause the whole plant to weaken. The key issue is that leaves need sunlight for photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a function of sepals?

options.text: Protecting the flower in the bud stage
Supporting the base of the flower
Being green in colour, they may carry out some photosynthesis

questions.explanation_correct: Producing pollen grains is the function of the anther (part of the stamen), not the sepals. Sepals protect the bud, support the flower base, and being green, may carry out some photosynthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sepals do protect the bud (correct), support the flower base (correct), and being green can do some photosynthesis (correct). But producing pollen is done by stamens (anthers), not by sepals.

questions.question_text: A farmer wants to grow wheat and carrot in adjacent fields. Which statement about their root systems is correct?

options.text: Wheat has fibrous roots and carrot has a tap root
Wheat has a tap root and carrot has fibrous roots

questions.explanation_correct: Wheat is a monocot plant with fibrous roots and parallel venation. Carrot is a dicot plant with a tap root system (the carrot itself is the enlarged tap root) and reticulate venation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wheat and carrot have different root systems. Wheat has fibrous roots (many thin roots), and carrot has a tap root (one main root, which is what we eat). Only option C correctly identifies both.

questions.question_text: Watermelon plant spreads along the ground because it is a:
questions.explanation_correct: Watermelon is a creeper because it has a weak stem that cannot stand upright and spreads along the ground. Other creepers include pumpkin, cucumber, and bottle gourd.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Herbs stand upright with soft stems. Trees are tall and upright. Climbers grow upward using support. The watermelon plant spreads along the ground, making it a creeper.

questions.question_text: The part of the pistil where pollen grains land during pollination is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The stigma is the topmost part of the pistil where pollen grains land during pollination. It is usually sticky to help the pollen grains attach to it. From the stigma, pollen tubes grow down through the style to reach the ovary.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ovary is at the base of the pistil and contains ovules. The style connects stigma to ovary. The anther is part of the stamen (male part). The stigma is specifically the landing surface for pollen.
